748FE5A62E2D4FF6AF35308A84F7597B.description: The  student  will  be  able  to  begin to  evaluate  why  historians often compartmentalize history into themes.

BF570A0633AA4BEDB4A9D1FC9FFC3C7C.description: The  student  will  be  able  to  recognize consistent themes  across  India,  China  and  Japan  and  replicate  these  themes  with  their  own  created  societies  via  projects.

A38B3F70217E460E88401AD1967B16A6.description: The  student  will  be  able  to  explain how  geography  frequently  impacts  how  India,  China  and  Japan  have  developed throughout history.

61C47926F65547B09845299091A809CE.description: The  student  will  be  able  to  describe  how  major  Eastern  Civilizations  often  follow  a  pattern  of  uniting,  destabilizing,   collapsing   into   conflicting   kingdoms   before seemingly inevitably reuniting again.

33A1183FE9704B1B889EA3201C0E4EBB.description: The student will be able to  explain how Authority,   Cultural   Constructs,   Cross   cultural       interactions,       geography,       technology,  trade  and  the  environment  act   as   common   themes   in   Eastern   Civilizations.

31C2502A6DBF425180F816C7A2887158.description: The student will be able to draw parallels between the Nanjing Massacre and the atomic bombs dropped on Japan. Insofar as both are acts of great inhumanity to man.

2E23A0C80A0C433A85DECF2CB2DD2609.description: Students  will  analyze  the  war-time  atrocities  and  the  circumstances that led to them.

AFA7B099C4D740829BEE968ABC791875.description: War-time  Atrocities  and  Conflict  during  World war II.

306FD66CD6E443EC8A6F064573288682.description: The student will be able to explain the racial aspect of interpreting history

17172E402EA944E6BB56F060177F7C33.description: The student will be able to analyze the reasons behind the  contributions  of  Asian  people  to  WW1  being  so  often overlooked.

62C1E54B91394A8BA1CCD7A565E64CAB.description: The student will be able to describe the contributions of Asians to WW1.

C6DC641384684333A57F5D854A1F17DC.description: The Contributions of the Asian Nations to World War I in Europe

5972CB0DE0894008BE8D59998BFAE061.description: The student will be able to  trace the rise of Sun Yat Sen.

444AD61D2D8B4DFFBF26CB858C16FE15.description: The student will be able to analyze how the resistance to  white  colonialism  led  to  the  rise  of  nationalist  sentiments  across  China  and  the  eventual  overthrow  of the Qing Dynasty.

CE8AA69E65864508BD9A9EDB711E17D9.description: The student will be able to highlight the infrastructure and policies left behind by the different colonizers.

33DF3509A07548EB900E564D773026D6.description: The  student  will  be  able  to map  out  how  European  colonialism reshaped India and Southeast Asia.

2F832CA81E384AF6B3FE0CD361A04F60.description: The  Legacy  of  the  Foreign  Occupation  in India and Southeast Asia

FE3A54D2E4004274A6BE13274F418B9F.description: The student will be able to explain why the events after the Opium Wars are considered the Hundred Years of Humiliation for China.

1FDA024AE1B241979A6B00FA9FD2BBD7.description: The student will be able to list out the reasons why the Qing dynasty failed to modernize.

41FCDCA70CD64F7AB61CFFE6685E8D50.description: Failure   to   Self-Strengthen   and   the   Consequences of the Opium Wars

9A8C860D8CEE450D9680AB57E4665CF5.description: The student will be able to contrast the failure of China to modernize with Japans success.

B22B9E75E44447608713CA531AAF8F5F.description: The student will be able to draw connections between how the ambition to modernize led to Japan colonizing smaller countries across Asia.

397B2B0F4F90409C8495DF2073AAD50F.description: The  student  will  be  able  to explain  how  the  Meiji  Restoration gave more power to the emperor and the individuals around him.

DC632CC62EA74A62B09B6F85B752EA37.description: Meiji     Restoration     and     Japanese     Ambition Expanding across East Asia

488AB2F903E6485697ED16A1E3D23172.description: Students   will   consider   the   differences   between ‘Westernization’ and ‘Modernization’.

31863BCFD065422B8DE0E0E90170ABCF.description: Students will examine how the restructuring of Japan led to a civil war.

05DF02211E404DB9976CE875BCA5A2C0.description: The student will be able to draw parallels between how Matthew Perry forced the reopening of Japan with how the British forced their way into China.

7C918DD3FF204ED6B4035CCAC6ECA4C7.description: External  and  Internal  unrest  in  Japan  after the arrival of Commodore Matthew Perry

0DE81D6D834D4A49ADB9D6539D8BDCB7.description: The student will be able to interpret how mercantilism led  to  the  rise  of  the  Honorable  East  India  Company  and its takeover of continental India.

C0A6738CA9484C7CB5DE7A6F0664B96F.description: The  student  will  be  able  to explain  how  European  mercantilism drove colonialism around the world.

119AAC353EF346CB8BB92214A3CAA8FC.description: The Rise of Mercantilism and East India Company’s Occupation of India

2CC398E173E149B8A09205065AA680D6.description: Students  will  explain  how  the  Manchu’s  created  and  expanded an empire based on tributary relations.

5536DC1203664B4D80D31BD889974024.description: Students will learn how the Manchus entered China as foreigners  to  create  a  Chinese  identity  and  establish  an ethnic hierarchy.

0363000559E5483598A3380D1724CC5A.description: The    Manchu    Conquest    and    the    Expansion of the Imperialist Qing

1E38135637AE492E8A64B685BCE8A3E0.description: Students  will  be  introduced  to  the  various  Southeast  Asian  and  Korean  kingdoms  and  how  they  were  influenced by China and India

33A39FEBF61541CAB6CEB8DFFF116673.description: Development of Kingdoms in Southeast Asia and Korea

725289C8E8A64A8A98FEDE5CADAD68D7.description: The  student  will  be  able  to  compare the  thematic  similarities     between     Chinese     and     Japanese     isolationism.

6AC29A86158841EE949AC075D25C1225.description: Students  will  examine  the  causes  and  effects  of  theban on foreigners in Edo Japan, particularly its effects on innovation and politics.

5440856609DB4360887EC1F811FB802A.description: The   Expulsion   of   Foreigners   from   Tokugawa Japan

B65E4F3D81104D09B394BB48D3CF4FC7.description: Students will examine the spheres of influence of the Ming Dynasty.

5BF556DA03914EB4B0AE963A0C17A8BA.description: Students  should  analyze  how  the  end  of  Zheng  He’s  expeditions enclosed China in a bubble of ego.

7D5AE26981644987AD631D79BAF97D1D.description: Students will explore the journey of Zheng He and his role   in   spreading   Chinese   power   and   influence   throughout South East Asia.

29E7A62C4C55404D8297365F54A81BCD.description: The Expeditions  of  Zheng  He  and  the  Height of Chinese Power

525D808AE11E4AE7BC70DE594D3CAD21.description: The   student   will   be   able   to   compare the   stark   similarities and differences between the Chinese and Japanese hierarchy.

003AAC23D6FF4B1EBCBE9E2D2A58F49F.description: The  student  will  be  able  to compare  and  contrast  he  feudal samurais in Japan and the medieval knights in Europe.

B506D87960604F938E431269329249AC.description: Samurai  Culture  and  Social  Structures  in Feudal Japan

2F451447413C4196B9373EACD9413E96.description: The   student   will   be   able   to identify   the   start   of   Confucian scholar dominance over Chinese society.

11733CE0E20E40CF9F6E44D4FDAB6003.description: Students will examine how the revival of Confucianism into Neo-Confucianism shaped the social structures of Ming Dynasty China.

F41BEE8C66C544C48A9987C708BE1582.description: Neo-Confucianism         and         Social         Structures in Feudal China

E64001E68BCB4139A5FF22A731923AF0.description: Students  will  analyze  how  social  structures  changed  during the Mughal empire.

392BCFBE4AC24AB9B03D10D2B2A3C862.description: Fracturing and Social Structures Under the Mughal Rulers

A8E7D69F6E14423AA11CA44D6BAA980A.description: The student will be able to interpret why not everyone in India was on board with multi-culturalism.

4BF0F4A70433481682303E50A30EEF8C.description: Students will study how the Mughal empire embraced the multi-culturalism of their nomadic ancestors.

3E2C9F1D8CC04E2BBAA7679B36076ED6.description: The   Creation   and   Development   of   Mughal India

EE2B8289AB88497996D03E68205998B8.description: The  student  will  be able  to  draw  similarities  between  how  the  Ming  and  the  Mughal  dynasties  handled  multiculturalism.

7D4F7EF22C634D05807D5407AA6974F5.description: Students  should  understand  why  the  Ming  dynasty  introduced what is now seen as a nationalistic agenda to wipe out the multi-culturalism of the Yuan Dynasty.

6C6D365DDD6E4C8F9EE41335C8505CDC.description: Restoration  of  the  Chinese  Identity  in  Ming China

15A063CA31D548BAB480C2A40DDF0CA9.description: The  student  will  be  able  to explain  how  the  Mongol  invasion led to the rise of the Samurai class.

C6C7B13A2F7B4565B7A8742475BD8A07.description: Students   will   examine   how   the   Mongol   invasion   reshaped Japanese society.

C1E5544BCE2C4421BBC7AB14AE3D5767.description: Repelling    the    Mongol    Invaders    in    Kamakura Japan

D936D8DD880445528F7EEC5B3C40492D.description: The  student  will  be  able  to interpret  and  weigh  the  benefits,   such   as   religious   freedom   and   cultural   diffusion,  against  the  Mongol’s  brutal  methods  of  conquest and the relatively short life of their Empire.

42654EF3132C4352A6BB6A567CF07152.description: The student will be able to analyze the pros and cons of the Mongol conquest.

DF10EB8F8AC545DC8E62123BF9BDE32C.description: The Positive and Negative Effects of the Expansion of the Mongol Empire

A1E67588B42A41A8BE7CFE8675035C49.description: The   student   will   be   able   to   compare   competing theories  of  the  decline  of  Buddhism  and  determine  their own conclusions.

61BD4C8FB32A4F64ADBEF7BFAEBADA0C.description: The  student  will  be  able  to  analyze the  changes  that  the  introduction  of  Islam  brought  to  Indian  society,  particularly the decline of Buddhism.

846E7EA31C8444DD8AD7ACFCDB2E9D67.description: Transition   to   a   Multi-Cultural   India   during the Muslim Conquest

1FC8F664BE194C4D9528D082C69DE29E.description: The student will be able to identify the significance of Oda Nobunaga in the continuity of a re-unified Japan

DEAD0960408B47E39EAFC5AFED66C975.description: The  student  will  be  able  to  explain the  role  of  the  Shogun.

283FD07CE50B478D85AE91F5B6B374E8.description: The  student  will  be  able  to  understand how  the  Japanese Emperor managed to remain on the throne throughout the chaos the Sengoku Jidai.

F3CAB37BB8454239BD39628ABC0C8D4C.description: The  Imperial  Power  and  the  Warring  States during Sengoku Japan

5A0B60CBAC244A68AF5E9997D5C8FA19.description: The  student  will  be  able  to begin  to  analyze  the  role  Romance    of    Three    Kingdoms    has    played    in    romanticizing  modern  Chinese  interpretations  of  the  Three Kingdoms Period.

485CE945E1D9412DB2D3224EE0101A94.description: The student will be able to identify the continuity and change   found   between   the   Romance   of   Three   Kingdoms and the Record of Three Kingdoms

05BC3D29536D45299BB0D681BBCF0431.description: Periods of Unity and Disunity during the Three Kingdoms

11B0EBD515A5431DBC4658A610EF71B8.description: The  student  will  be  able  to draw  thematic  parallels  between  the  Gupta  period  and  classical  Tang  and  Song China.

428ABDB8729744908E38DF34F56B56C6.description: Students  will  outline  the  characteristics  of  the  Gupta  empire which allowed it to rapidly develop in the fields of science and mathematics.

211275EFAE4440638D157D523C6ED3E8.description: Development  of  science  and  medicine  in the Gupta period

093FE1BE8D134BDCBD7DD5B10A38A763.description: The  student  will  be  able  to draw  conclusions  by  comparing the maps of Chang’an, Kyoto and Nara.

068A9D12EF92450082296C27D2F037D8.description: Students  will  understand  how  the  Heian  period  took  classical Tang culture and adopted it as their own

F61A204F742C46E3B24A103FEA25D8EE.description: The  Assimilation  of  Chinese  culture  in  the Heian Period

C5181050B15B49E9816E60F199BA9A1D.description: The student will be able to study ceramics and water painting as primary sources from the Tang and Song dynasty.

382229A4B4D34E5C95B0FD00DE062179.description: The student will be able to explain why China stood as the center of culture and art in Asia.

A9365EB7B585470BA5E7A0AB1F176A12.description: The student will be able to analyze life in the Tang and Song Dynasties.

4D76810B6ADA42B79DE8491320C83667.description: Flourishing   Art   and   Architecture   in   Classical Tang and Song

AE5B9ECACC484C10BADDD5F274953FB2.description: The   student   will   be   able   to describe   the   Three   Kingdoms  Period  of  Korea  and  how  it  thematically  connected to ‘Greater China’.

F7C31F48A4DE4593A711E623B7355366.description: The  student  will  be  able  to understand  how  Korea  functioned as a cross-road between China and Japan.

925FF3C45D7E45A0B575C56BAB2DD433.description: The  Cultural  Exchanges  from  Korea  to  Japan.

FB0A4D8EDDFE4C4FB0CB44F076F757DB.description: The student will be able to analyze how geographical positioning led to the development of the Silk Road.

014AD243A67A473084CE5469EED76C07.description: The  student  will  be  able  to map  out  how  the  Han  dynasty  strengthened  and  expanded  along  the  Silk  Road.

AA87063E85074E3DA4B4E13FECB06109.description: Cultural  influence  of  the  Han  through  trade on the Silk Road.

0FE51DD076B7491695AB0703C6676FD6.description: Students will be exposed to how the spice trade led to some early historical themes concerning trade.

8F469FF21CE14A53A2FA339B649CB4E3.description: Students  will  analyze  the  life  of  Ashoka and  how  he  contributed   to   the   spread   of   Indian   culture   and   Buddhism.

F9EF3A2C8CCB41C28EBD868E01470E69.description: The student will be able to discuss the different ways culture diffuses along the Silk Road.

6BC211FF8D514C909969654979594C08.description: The first Indian Empires and the Spread of Culture through the Silk Road.

E67A2C10F5744B1191D89AB4A8FF4129.description: Students will examine the continuity of how Buddhism helped define the modern Indian cultural identity.

123D0D3F50614A8288429AC2871A9160.description: The student will be able to explain how the pressures of Hinduism led to the formation of Buddhism.

371985B154914F5EAA590D8D49B7520F.description: The    Formation    of    Hinduism    and    Buddhism in India

2F6BE4F53E214105B86BD355C5F24D1A.description: Students will examine the continuity of how Shintoism helped define the modern Japanese cultural identity

E14A6E2242784B42BB4714A3F00F9D79.description: The  student  will  be  able  to understand  the  core  concepts    behind    worshipping    nature    and    how    Shintoism shaped Japanese society.

8FD1FA7C2C934C1CAE6EB84912BB68A8.description: Nature Worship and Shintoism in Japan

4A17E3F97D894E1BB313D44D2E8B880F.description: Students  will  examine  the  continuity  of  how  Chinese  religion and ideology played a role in the formation of the Han Chinese cultural identity today.

490C2C15457C46E79C5901A6FEA25D30.description: The student will be able to compare and contrast the three major philosophies of Ancient China

38FEABB0F8DA42E5878514D7602E7CB8.description: The student will be able to distinguish the differences between  the  major  philosophies  which  developed  during the Zhou Dynasty.

9BABB84EBA6E4BC08A2AC0F7BF57367A.description: The     Spread     and     Importance     of     Philosophy in China

3BEDD4F0716F44CA823FD68101C42387.description: The student will be able to analyze the most significant changes brought about by the Qin Emperor.

39F1E592481D4F62B9936F4BBDA624C7.description: Students  will  compare  contrast  the  processes  that  formed  the  QinDynasty  compared  to  the  Yamato  Dynasty.

8FB7C5B4881048C59A9C958F0E0E7E3F.description: Centralized  Government  under  the  Qin  Emperor

CF27F19380874E67A90679F99E83A888.description: The student will be able to interpret the significance of the Aryans in shaping the life and culture of early India, i.e.; the caste system.

B05B9DA659084EBDBAEBE92739A02294.description: The Arrival of the Aryans and the Caste System

11E7901BF8BE43BE81937A6CC90677C0.description: The   student   will   be   able   to describe   how   the   preservation of the Yamato line became a center point of Japanese politics.

735F4E45CBE544F59100B2994A124B30.description: Students will compare and contrast the processes that formed  the  Yamato  Emperors  compared  to  the  Qin  Dynasty.

AFE17567E331485B84934BE53398DE73.description: The  Start  of  the  Imperial  Lineage  in  Yamato Japan

1142E836374B45DD8661C49387AB87DE.description: The student will be able to compare and contrast the quick progression of the river valley civilizations of the Indus and Yellow river to the slow development of the Jomon culture on the Island of Japan.

E9F0DC37CDC34CADBF8E0CA282D49755.description: The  student  will  be  able  to explain  how  geography  plays a part in the growth of civilization.

AD9B359CC3BE4ABDBC02E7B795F6AD02.description: The Effect of Geography on the Growth of Civilizations

37122D23BF8D4E8B94DC964712697B6E.description: The student will be able to use historical thinking skills to draw conclusions about how myths connect to the real world.

42063664468F4C1D97E5484B17556576.description: The  student  should  be  able  to  distinguish  between  myths and empirical facts.

2EC6E36419354551A99065BB0D38D9A0.description: Comparison   of   Creation   Myths   and   Empirical Evidence

74BBCB87DA2743D99C9025CC4F85EFDF.description: The   student   will   be   able   to   identifyways   that   diverse/alternative  evidence  could  be  used  to  qualify  or modify an argument.

A9A581F4A17F45E381C2D0A496B39D38.description: The  student  will  be  able  to  articulate a  historically  defensible   claim   that   describes   the   relationship   between 3-4 pieces of historically relevant evidence.

742F7D8890DD424CB6678D76E07D9D20.description: The student will be able to explain how the evidence they  are  using  supports  a  historical  claim  they  have  made.

B6CDB59C232F4AEEBB10F741398FBA44.description: The student will be able to state a plausible historical claim based on evidence. The student will be able to draw a conclusion from a simplistic piece of historical evidence.

EEFBD7AB9E9E4268854BC972F07BF8F0.description: Make   a   defensible   claim   using   3-4 relevant pieces of historical evidence.

976B6C9247504E589D4A22132AE0A9BE.description: The student will be able to analyze the intentions of a secondary source.

31CDDC43C7084D64A56C4AB855CA78E1.description: The student will be able to analyze the intentions of a primary source.

EBF60E76855A4800AC5D9688B432BDF4.description: Students will be able e to explain the main ideas of a secondary source.

D3EB7ED6A4FE4EA4A3A84E2C5032C1F7.description: Students will be able e to explain the main ideas of a primary source.

852877ADEB9C42478E5851342B6F5A7A.description: The student will be able to summarize the main ideas of a secondary source.

F478FAA45E934B67A414C3B7A9F0601D.description: The student will be able to summarize the main ideas of a primary source

A6A3D55937224F9F889F6F10337E6B01.description: The student will be able to analyze how the history of Eastern  Civilizations  resulted  in  the  establishment  of  the  world  they  live  in  today,  taking  into  consideration  the  cultural/political/economic/geographical  changes  over time.

09720222C9F54FC9B3077C8A75B16103.description: The  student  will  be  able  to produce  extended  writing  which compares how at different points in time China, Japan   and   India   develop   more   rapidly   than   one   another.

FF5D514B975A4448878079E7E69ECD26.description: The  student  will  be  able  to contrast  the  different  speeds at which China, Japan and India develop.

1B8D486DC17D48AA9BE5794EFC22873C.description: The student will be able to create timelines and other graphical    demonstrations    of    Japanese    Periods,    Chinese and Indian Dynasties.

6A94C18497644CC093F848076BB44CCE.description: The  student  will  be  able  to explain  how  Golden  Ages/Disunity/Reunification  and  other  key  themes  of  Eastern Civilizations lead into one another.

6BC5CADB7A7C4A57B683A51277424BAE.description: The  student  will  be  able  to accurately  remember  the  chronological development of Eastern Civilizations.

E93DC179239A40208FE3FE0730D8452C.description: The  student  will  be  able  to evaluate  which  Eastern  Civilizations     were     most     influenced     by     their     geographical conditions.

2A8B95B40391486F8BD899968034580A.description: The  student  will  be  able  to analyze  to  what  extent  geographical conditions influenced the development of Eastern Civilizations.

430C418246934F79AC59847F03A2F3A9.description: The  student  will  be  able  to  apply  their  knowledge  to  maps  to  demonstrate  how  Eastern  Civilizations  were  heavily influenced by geography.

FE690FA6301F4281B428B33845DDCA54.description: The  student  will  be  able  to explain  how  geographic  conditions  have  impacted  how  Eastern  Civilizations  have influenced one another.

3AE8B7FA827A4912920B7E18C141BBE5.description: The student will be able to remember how geographic conditions  have  influenced  how  Eastern  Civilizations  have developed.

38AB16DE1F7141CEB0DCD43907DA0527.description: The  student  will  be  able  toevaluate  with  critical  precision    if    individual    historical    events    being    removed/altered  would  actually  considerably  different  continuity.

4D9217DE8D974DE285DFAB4C3778D768.description: The   student   will   be   able   to illustrate   alternative   historical  consequences  based  upon  the  removal  or  substitution     of     historical     events     for     Eastern     Civilizations.

EB7A031175204166ADCF580E85FE4879.description: The  student  will  be  able  to distinguish  and  appraise  how   changes   to   technology,   social   belief   politics,   economics, at different times have a greater impact on the history of Asia.

275E03AACA10451888E128CEA47DE884.description: The  student  will  be  able  to  interpret  which  events  in  Eastern Civilizations led to more important and/or less important changes for Eastern Civilizations.

1B6D131305A447FE817F8399640C2AD0.description: The student will be able to explain the significance of both  important  events  and  gradual  developments  to  Eastern Civilizations which led to historical moments or significant changes for Eastern Civilizations

60886089EB18483F8C54BE0C55729250.description: The  student  will  be  able  to identify  how  particular  events in Eastern history led to significant changes to Eastern Civilizations.

39CE7120030B49F4B648D5153C26DC1D.description: The  student  will  be  able  to engage  in  self-directed research to develop their own conclusions concerning significant events in Eastern Civilizations.

7D3CC640031B4279810998DECF825AD4.description: The   student   will   be   able   to draw   upon   different   historical sources, relating to Eastern Civilizations and use them to develop critical judgements presented in written format.

809E1BC6A7934471BA0A8138E380B2F1.description: The  student  will  be  able  to compose  argumentative  essays  which  include  a  simple  thesis,  use  specific  evidence and generate a targeted analysis.

EEE91EAABFAE4BC38E85F6223F35159C.description: The   student   will   be   able   to present   historical   arguments in both written and oral form.

4E651E0EB2674C43933292AFE52ED19F.description: The  student  will  be  able  to explain  commonly  held  opinions and assumptions about Eastern Civilizations and may be able to correctly identify misconceptions.

E74CB398E3314D48A9C39A747832071F.description: The student will be able to summarize the main ideas and   events   of   significant   moments   in   Eastern   Civilizations.
